div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: 60 STONES.
div.p: YEARS OF AWFUL AGONY. CURED BY DOAN’S BACKACHE KIDNEY PILLS.
When interviewed—18 months after her cure—by one of our representatives, Mrs. M. Hughes, 70, Latimer Street, Liverpool, England, said: -“I am most pleased to endorse my previous statement.”

The following is the story of Mrs. Haghes’ illness, in her own words: “I first bad medical treatment nine years ago, and the doctor told me that my trouble arose from the kidneys and that it would be necessary to draw the water from my body with an instra- ment ; my back was frightful. Por nearly three years before I called in the doctor I had been suffering from stabbing pains that used to strike right across the small of my back. At times I would have to stand to get my breath antil the pain eased—it was like a knife being driven into my back. When at last I saw the doctor the pains were so bad and I was in such a serious state that I had taken to my bed. I also soffered terribly from urinary troubles. I ailed all over, suffering from a ter rible pressing pain at the top of my head, which made me feel as if it would finally drive me demented ; there were also shooting pains in the temples, rheumatic pains, hot flushes and cold chills, and I used to have a dragging, tired feeling which made me disinclined to go out of doors at all or even to talk to anybody.

“Off and on the doctor treated me for three years, similar attacks coming on all the time then I tried a second doctor, and at last I made up my mind to see what Doan’s Backache Kidney Pills would do for me. I used two boxes and obtained no relief, and began to fear that they would do me no good. But toward the end of the third box the urine began to pass more freely. After that stones began to come away, at first small, about the size of peas, and after that larger, some of them as large as a small bean. There was great pain while passing them, bat otherwise I began to feel much better. In all I passed 60 stones, using the pills for months according to directions. My health has been first-rate ever since.

Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 13 P.T. per box, or 71 P.T. for 6 boxes ;or they may be had direct from the agents for Egypt, Mr. E. Del Mar, Rue Hotel du Nil, and Rue Moasky, Cairo ; Rue Tewfik, (opposite the Bourse), Alex andria, and Roe Commerciale, Port Said ; and Measers 8. Fischer, and Co., RneSheriff Pacha, Alexandria

Established 1880

Price: One Piastre Tariff
MONDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1907.
DANGERS OF MODERATE DRINKING.

‘The effect of a small daily dose of alcohol on animals is set by Professor Taav. Laitinen, of Helsi in a paper laid before the International Anti-Aleohol Congress atStockholm, of which an accdunt is given by Mr. Theodore Neild in the “British Journal of Inebriety”’.

“Prof. Laitinen began by reminding us that former results which he had from time to timepublished had been obtained by the administration of larger doses—never less than 0.5 gramme for each kilogramme that the animal in question weighed. He had felt that it was of great importance, however, to try how far the resistivity of animals was effected, and in’ what directions, when the doses administered each day were so small as 0.1 gramme.

“The writer, when at Helsingfors, was told by Prof. Laitinen that this amount wool mean, in the case of a man of average weight, a glass of Finnish beer daily, and the glass seemed hardly aslargeas that used in England. In order to detéct the influence of these very small doses, Prof. Laitinen has kept his research animals—guinea pigs and rabbits—in a perfectly equipped place. He employed « large number of animals, and, of course, treated them all alike, even to the handling during the administration of the liquids. The only difference was that some had water alone, and others the same quantity of water with such an amount of alcohol mixed with it as to get 0.1 gramme of alcohol per kilogramme of their respective weights. The two sets were so treated for eight months. To detect the altera tion in resistivity, Dr. Laitinen availed himself of the most delicate methods of research and biological reactions. In the first place, the resistivity of the animals (the aleoholised animals and the control or non-aleoholi- sed animals was tested either by aato- infection or by inoculation (guinea pigs) with the toxin of diphteria. This showed the alcoholised animals to have less resistivity The difference was clearly to be recognise. In the case of forty rabbits exposed to infection for four months the lessened immunity was as forty-five to sixty-five, and where death ens.ed the duration of disease was as 18.6 to 21.7 days in the alcohulished and control animals respectively.

Of the young born of alcoholised rabbits 61.29 per cent. died, and of those born of control animals 54.17 per cent. died. The young of the alcoholished rabbits, when three days old, weighed on a average 79 grammes, and grew during the next twenty days 7.13 grammes daily on an average. The young of those treated with water only, weighed 87.9 grammes at birth, and grew at the rate of 9 46 grammes per diem.

“The difference is still clearer when we come to the guinea pigs Of the young of those treated with water alone 21.74 per cent. only died ; whilst, on the other hand, the proportion in the case of the alcoholised animals was 36.76 per cent. The progeny of the former weighed at birth on an average 77.31 grammes, grew in the first ten days 4.12 grammes daily. The young of the latter- the aloobolised animals—on the other hand, were on an — 78.41 grammes at birth, and grew in rs twenty days 4.30 grammes daily. When he carried on his weighings for 110 days the difference was as 4.86 grammes to 5.50 gram- mes. He began with seventy animals and ended with 348, having had more than 600 pass through his hands. It constitutes one of the most important researches of modern times, and its findings must exercise a great influence apon our attitade towards what is now regarded as the most moderate use of alcohol as a beverage.”

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
The "Sudan Times"
div.p: Our Khartoum contemporary entered on the’fifth year of its history last week.

div.head: Bubonio Plague.
div.p: There were eight cases of plague under treatment on the 19th October, this bringing the total for the year up to 1,117.

div.head: The Tourah Murders.
div.p: Mobamed Osman, who recently murdered two of his fellow-prisoners at Tourah, will be brought before the Cairo Criminal Court to- day

div.head: Fatal Fall from Lacdder.
div.p: A native workman employed on the building ot a house in the Abdeen district, Cairo, on Friday, slipped and fell from the top of a lad der and was killed instantaneously.

div.head: Sir E. Gorst’s Reports.
div.p: The rumour which is current to the effect that Sir Eldon Gorst will discontinue the writing of annual reports, as done by Lord Cromer, is, we are authorized to state, entirely without foundation

div.head: Nemesis
div.p: A certain Bessioni, a well-known criminal of the Behera province and one suspected of more than one cold-blooded murder, has been found ina field at Damanhour, with his body riddled by half a dozen revolver shots.

div.head: Omdurman’s Water.
div.p: The work of digging ditches for laying water-pipesat Omdurman will be commenced this week. It is believed that Omdurman will yet have its water-works in fall working order, before Khartoum, though the pipes were buried in the streets more than a year and a half ago.

div.head: Murder at Dessouk.
div.p: On the night of Saturday last a tenant of the esbeh of Mr. George Charidis in the Des- souk Markaz was murdered by a well-known brigand, named Aly-Abou-Awad. He was arrested by the polive after the murder and taken to Dessouk. The same man committed a marder near Tantah two months ago, but was liberated twenty day afterwards!

div.head: Commeroial Evening Sohool.
div.p: Mr. Fred. J. Ney, Headmaster of St. Mary's Schools, Kasr el Doubara, Cairo, is organising in connection with these an evening commer cial school, which should supply a long felt want in the Capital. The classes which Mr. Ney proposes holding are commercial corres pondence in English, French, and (erman, office routine, shorthand, typewriting, book keeping, commercial arithmetic and geography, and the science of natural and commercial products.

div.head: The Legisiative Council
div.p: At a meeting held on Saturday, under the presidency of Abdel Hamed Pasha Sadik, the Legislative Council debated the motion of Sheikh Aly Youssef, whereby it was proposed to sybmit all regulations regarding public instruction to the Council before promulgation, and approving of the principal of the motion have appointed a committee composed of Ismail PaSha Abaza, Mohammed Eloni Pasha, Mahmoud Abdel Gaffar Bey, and Mohammed ‘Trammam Habarir Bey, to farther investigate and report on the proposal

div.head: Abduction of a Child.
div.p: The other day a Jew of the name of Abdulla Yacouh went to the Esbekieh Gardens with his seven year old son, whom he allowed to ran about and play at his own will. Shortly afterwards the man looked for his son but could not find him, but before many minutes had elapsed an Italian approached him and said that he could restore to him his son on payment ot a ransom. The distracted father attempted to seize hold of the Italian, who, however, was took quick for him, and nothing remained for the man to do but to give in formation to the police of the abduction of of his son. So far no news of the Italian's capture has been received

div.head: The Inniskilling Fusiliers.
div.p: The farewell concert given by the 2ud Battalion of the Royal Inniskilling lusiliers, at the Grand Continental Hotel on Saturday night proved to be an immense success. Dinner was served on the terrace, the band being stationed at the farther end, and one might almost have imagined that the season had commenced by the number of people who had assembled. We owe a big debt of thanks to the officers of the regiment frequently allowed its band to perform for the public benefit, and also to Mr. lt. Watson Ramsey, the bandmaster, whose familiar figure, together with those of the men whom he condnets, will be sadly missed in Cairo.

div.head: THE ZIZINIA MERTING.
div.p: Mustapha Pasha Kamel will arrive at Alex- andria from Cairo at 3 o'clock this afternoon and will be greeted at the Bab-el-Ghedid terminus by his friends and adherents.

The authorities of the Alexandria Gouver- norat are taking precautions to prevent any disturbance of.the public peace on the occasion of the demonstration at the Zizinia theatre to- morrow evening. No less than thirty police- man will be at the theatre or in its immediate neighbourhood to cope with any distarb- ances and it is hoped that the meeting will pass off without any trouble or disorder.
The Pasha’s followers at Alexandria state that great numbers of natives from the Behera Province and other parts of the Delta are flocking into the city in order to attend the meeting.

Much anxiety reigns among the suppcrters of Mustapha Pasha Kamel as to the success of to-morrow’s meeting at the Zizinia Theatre. Great efforts are being made to organise a demonstration on the occasion of the “Patriot's” visits to Alexandria, but Kamel’s emissaries are obliged to confess that there is very little real enthusiasm among the more respectable elements of the native population. There is no doubt that the theatre will be filled for if the worse comes to the worst there will be hundreds of Berberine and bowabs, who can be brought in to listen to the speech. Bat what is wanted by Kamel is a gathering of a very different sort and up to now, in spite of the energy displayed by the organisers, very little enthu- siasm is visible. Kamels’ supporters attribote this falling-off in his popularity to the malign influence of the Moderate Nationalist Party and accuse “Al Moayad” and “Al Minbar” of having brought about the disaffection. As the object of the Pasha’s visit to Alexandria is to prove that he ought to be the only leader ot the Nationalist Party and his newspaper, “Al Lewa,” the only organ of the movement, it is only natural that the newspapers of Sheikh Aly Youssef and Hafiz Effendi Awad should exert themselves to the utmost to connteract Kamel.

div.head: NATIONALISTIC JOURNALISM
div.p: The French edition of the “Egyptian Standard” declares that the recent changes in the English edition of Mustapha Pasha Kamel’s English organ are due to the fact that ithas been thought advisable to entrast all responsibility of and editing that newspaper to a native and that is why Mr. Rady has been relieved of responsibility. ‘“L’Egypte” in an account of these changes in Mr. Rudy's position remarks apropos of that gentleman
Ilpargit cependant que son dévouement n'a pas été apprécié et qu'il sucoombe sous les intrigues de l'entourage' fanatique et a courtes vues du pacha agitateur

div.head: THE MODERATE NATIONALISTS
div.p: The quarrel between the violent and fanatical section of the Nationalist Party, led by Kamel, and the Moderate Nationalists has reached such an acute stage that Sheikh Aly Youssefin an article in “Al Moayad” demands that legal proceedings should be resorted to in order to stop the fanatical tury of Kamel aud his clique. The Sheikh's words are “the fall of tactics of passion and folly will call for the punishment by having recourse to justice) of the actions of the furious men.” In the course of the same article he says, “we have no longer any need henceforth to enter into discussion with this deluded fellow, who has been made blind and deat owing to folly and lack of reflection Heisno longer capable of understanding and can only regard himself. In madhouses there are numbers of fools and lunatics of the same kind as the man whom we are now dealing with.” It is need less to staté that these words refer to Mustapha Pasha Kamel. ‘The relations between Sheikh Aly Youssef and the Kbedivial Court make these remarks specially noteworthy. This article of “Al Moayad” has caused consider able discussion and it is expected that it will lead to further defections among Kamel’s followers, many of whom have become some: what nervous of late owing to his fanatical policy

div.head: THE PRESENT SITUATION
div.p: Many supporters of the British Oceupation will doubtless hold that the acute dissensions now prevailing among the various groups of the Nationali ts is an unfailing sign of the bankruptey of the whole movement. This is quite an erroneous standpoint to take. During the latter portion of Lord Cromer’s rule he became more and more unpopular with a large section of the Moslem Native public. Whether the grounds for this unpopularity were in any way justified or not does not concern us here, but the attitude ofthe leading Moslem newspapers, the protests of the nat ive members of the Alexandria Municipality in regard to the Memorial, and various other examples of the same sort amply demonstrated that such was the case. This opposition to Lord Cromer's policy gave an air of cohesion to the native Press: Although the editors of "Al Lewa" and "Al Moayad" disliked one another then as heartily as they do now, they and their fellows were obliged to maintain an united front against theri common enemy. Under the circumstance it was natural that one man should come prominently foreward as the leader of the opposition and Mustapha Pasha Kamel gained this post. His extreme acuteness in the art of self-advertisement, his fluent French, his aquaintance with Europe and his pleasnt manners, whereby be obtained the sympathy of Madame Adam, Pierre Loti and many otherss, well fitted him for this temporary job.
His reivals, who always disliked his arrogance, had perfore to submit to this ascendency, for it was absolutelyy necessary for them to keep an

united front. As soon, however, as Lord Cromer retired from the struggle, the Nationalist Army resolved into its component and mutually hostile units and Mustapha's ascendency was gone never to return. He was useful as the pygmy protagonist of Eygptian Nationalism before the Cromeric Colossus, but as soon as the later retired Mustapha's rasion d'etre as the leader of the opposition disappeared and his journalistic compeers at once turned on him. He was a smart, useful man in his way, but his conceit renders him quite intolerable and he is now bitterly attacked by the very men, who were virtually serving under his banner a few months ago. These squabbles do not in any way signfy that Nationalism is dying a natural death. On the contray, however factiticous it may appear to be in Eygpt, it is part and parcel of that great movement towards racial self- consciousness, which is devloping simultaneously in other parts of world. The struggles, incident to the disposition of Mustapha are only a necessary phase in the movement. He has to go because he has served his turn and there is no more use for a leader of his type, or in fact for any leader at all. The meeting, which he has convened at the Zizina Theatre, is a vain attempt to fight against the fissiparous tendencies of the movement. To-morrow night will beat the big dream of Eygptian Nationalism and exhibit all of his old stock-in-trade with his usual facile eloquence, but it is quite hopeless for him ever again to try to get back to his old positition. With his habitual arrogance he flattered himself that he had borne a great part in bringing about Lord Cromer's retirement and rejoiced with great rejoicing thereat, whereas no event ought to have been a source of greater concern to him, for Lord Cromer's departure found Mustapha's occupation gone.

div.head: POLITICAL CHANGES.
div.p: Many natives appear to labour under the idea that vast changes are impending in every branch of the Administration and that Sir Eldon Gorst intends to effect radical changes in the system pursued by Lord Cromer.
In an article on political dreams and delusions “Al Watan” says :—

Coming nearer home we find that our own people hold strikingly similar views about chan- ges to come in the condition and Government of Egypt in consequence of the natural change in the person of the British Agent. Simply because Lord Cromer has resigned and Sir Eldon Gorst has come to take his place our friends of the class so common in all countries are dreaming, or rather asserting, changes in every branch so wild and so numerous that even the common mind revolts against accept- ing the whole prophesied bill. We hope to prove the fallacy of this last belief by visible and emphatic means now that the hero of the promised changes has come back from leave to work for the interests of his country and its friends and to further the cause of security and reform.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive will this week inspect the Mariout railway, which has now reach Ka teshi, a distance of 250 kilometres from the Tripolitan frontier, and 180 kilometres from Mariout

div.head: A ROYAL VISITOR
div.p: (From Ovr Own CORRESPONDENT) Port-Said, Monday. The S.S. “Birma” arrived here last night with the King of Siam aboard.His Majesty has transferred from the “Birma” to the Nord- deutscher Lloyd “Sachsen” by which he pro- ceeds on his journey this afternoon.

div.head: THE MECCA PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: The Egyptian Government has issued a cir cular relative to those who wish to accompany the Mahmal caravan to the Hedjaz.
This year, as in former years, the Govern- ment has decided to allow those who are desir- ons of 80 doing, and who undertake to submit to the prescribed conditions, to accompany the Mahmal caravan.

Those who take advantage of this offer of the Government will be placed under the pro- tection of the Emir el Hag and the military escort of the Mahmal. The journey will be accomplished by the shortest possible and least laborious route, and ahder especial condi- tions as regards comfort, safety, and . prestige. The cost of the expedition will be lessened by joining the caravan, as pilgrims will profit by the advantageous arrangements which the Emir el Hag is able to make regarding camels.

In so far as the expenses of the journey are concerned, experience has shown that the sums deposited in former years have been insufficier.t, and for the present year, as last year, it has been decided that those accompanying the Mahmal must make the following deposits, according to the degree of comfort they desire to travel in: LE. 25.500mm. for each first class pas- senger; including charge for one camel (an extra charge of LE 17 is made for every additional camel); L.B. 28 for the second class passenger with one camel ; LE. 20.500mm. for the third class passenger with one camel; L.E. 14 when one camel is shared by two pilgrims ; L.B. 10.500m. for every child from 4 to 10 years of age who shares a camel with another child or with a parent.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner ‘“Rameses” arrived this morning from Liverpool via Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malta, with passengers, mails and general cargo.
The S.S. “Adalia” of the Westcott and Laurance line left Malta on Saturday and is due here next Wednesday with general cargo from London and coals from Newoastle.

div.head: Lord Cromer and Freedom of City
div.p: MANSION ROUSE LUNCHEON.
( Gazette Special Service. ) Lowpon, Monday.

After the ceremony of the presentation of freedom of the city to Lord Cromer, the Lord Mayor will entertain his lordship to luncheon at the Mansion House. The guests will include Sir E. Grey, Rt. Hon John Morley, Lord Curzon, Lord Northbrook, the Marquis of Bath, Lord Revelstroke, Lord Granville, Lord Middleton, Sir Vincent Caillard, Sir Thomas Sutherland, and the Hon. Walter Rothschild.

div.head: ROADS FOR ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: To The Editor of the "Eygptian Gazette"

Sir,—In yesterday's issue of the “Egyptian Gazette” you published a very interesting aceotnt of the efforts that are being made by the Caird automobile club to open up roads in neighborhood of the Captial. The old Suez road, and the old road to Hawendier are also being looked after by the Club. Why is there no such institution at Alexandria? Surely we have enough motorists in this city to start an automobile clab ona permanent basis, which will take up the question of road improvements in the neighbourhood of this city. It is positively disgraceful that no good road should connect Alexandria and Aboukir. Another great want is the construction of a road over the lake to Mariout. The Mariout district would improve greatly if there was only road connection with this city, and the property thereabouts would be increased vastly in value if only there was some chance of getting there by motorcar. Until then that most healthy country will never be developed, while if it was joined to Alexandria by a road it would be sure to soon become a pleasant summer and spring resort for Alexandrians to have villas and bungalows. But as long as the only communication is by an infrequent series of trains Mariont will be neglected. These and many other questions ought to be taken up by the Alexandrian automobile club, were such a body in existence
Truly yours A Motorist. Alexandria, 20th October.

div.head: DJELALEDDIN PACHA ET LE SULTAN
div.p: Monsiear le Directeur de l “Egyptian Gazette”,

Permettes-moi d’opposer le démenti le plus formel aux bruits qne vous avez enregistrés dans le numéro d’hier de votre estimable jour- nal, au sujet de prétendues conditions que j’aurais formulées pour ma rentrée en Turquie.

Ma lettre au “Times” concernait des affaires d’ordre général ; il ne serait pas conforme & son esprit, moins encore & mon caractére que sa publication aboutisse a une di i in- téréts privés. Ceux qui propagent les nouvelles tendancieuses dont |’¢cho est arrivé jusga’a voas, jugent apparemment les choses d’an point de vue qui doit leur étre habitoel.
Je sais le peuple ture trop malheoreux et j'ai une trop haute conception de la dignité humaine pour admettre un seul instant Fide de donner une suite pareille A cette discussion politique.
Au surplus, je n'ai jamais envisagé la ques- tion de ma rentrée en Turquie; je pense que dans les circonstances actuelles 11 serait plus inopportun que jamais d'y songer.
J'ai l'honneur de vous présenter, Monsieur le Directenr, |'assurance de ma parfaite consi- dération.
Aumep DsrLacepprn. Le Caire le 19 Octobre 1907

div.head: SUDAN APPOINTMENTS.
div.p: The following appointments are announced:-

Mr. J. W. Sagar, Deputy Inspector, Jebel Sub-Province, to be Junior Inspector Jebel Sub-Province; Mr. S. A. Tippets, LAnd Settle- ment Officer, Legal Department, to be Junior Inspector, Kerdofan Provinee; Mr. C, F. Ryder, Surveyor, Survey Department; Mr. C. H. Walker, Commercial Inspector, Sudan Agent's Office, Cairo, to be Commercial Inspector, Central Economic Board, Khartoum.
Mr. E.N. Corbyn is appointed Settlement Officer for the Kamlin Dietrict of the Blue Nile Provinee.

Having regard to the uncertainity of certain parts of the boundary between the Blue Nile Province and the White Nile Province, he is also appointed Settlement Officer for such of the lands in the Geteina District of the White Nile Province adjoining or near to the said boundary as it may be nescessary or convenient to settle in connection with the settlement of the claims in the Kamlin District

Mr. H. St. G. Peacock continues Settlement Officer of the Blue Nile Province other than the Kamlin District and Mr. M. S. MacDonnell of the Geteina District of the White Nile Pro- vince, except as regards such lands ajoining or near the said boundary which shall have been settled by Mr. E. N. Corbyn

div.head: “PERSONAL AND SOCTAL.
div.p: There is no truth in the report that Sir Wililam Garstin has decided to leave the Government service in February néxt; he has as yet formed no plans relative to leaving.
Rear Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield arrived at Alexandria this morning by the Austrian Lioyd steamer. Lady Blomfield is not return. ing until November.
Sir John Rogers Pasha, Chairman of the Menzaleh Canal and Navigation Company, is leaving Marseilles on Wednesday by the 8.8. “Schleswig” and is due here on the 28th inst.
Mohamed Mohsen Pasha arrived yesterday from the Interior, where he spent a fortnight in inspecting his estates.
Constantine Cotta Bey, first Secretaty to the Council of Ministers, has returned from leave and resumed his functions.
Mrs. Hunter, wife of Lewa Hanter Pasha, has returned to Cairo from England.
Judge and Miss Batcheller arrived at Alex- andria this morning by the S.S. “Ismailia”
Mr. H, P. C. Parkinsof, imanager of the Khedivial Mail Steamship and Graving Dock Company, Ltd., arrived at Alexandria this morning by the S.S. “Ismailia.”
Mr. Kingston has returned to Cairo from his holiday.
The Sultan has conferred the first class order of the Medjidieh on Ibrahim Barpau Pasha, of Alexandria, and the order of Shafakat on the Pasha’s daughter.
Mrs. Lindemann arrived at Alexandria this morning from Constantinople.
Mr. Clongh W. L. Bromley, of the National Bank of Egypt, left estate in the United Kingdom eitered at £1,483.
Among the arrivals by the Italian mail steamer were Marquis Fioravanti, Maitres Cambas, Lazzaries, Rossi, and Vitali, Mr. Anas tassiadis, Mr. A. Maller, and Mr. Colucci di Benedetti.

div.head: MILITARY NOTES.
div.p: Lewa Griffith Pasha, DS.0., late Principal Veterinary Officer to the Sudan Government, has been strack off the Egyptian Army from the 11th inst. The Khedive has bestowed the Order of the Medjidieh (2nd class) on him in recognition of his valaable services.
Major R.C. Stevenson, R.G.A., has joined the command (Army of Occupation) and d the duties of 0.C., R.A, in Egypt.
Major H. P. Protheroe-Smith, 0.U., M.M.P., has returned to Cairo from leave and resamed duty. He leaves the Capital to-day for Alex- andria on inspection duty.

Captain and Brevet Major H. A. Porter, D.S.0., King’s Liverpool Regiment, who has been posted for duty to the Egyptian Army, will be the second officer of the regiment doing duty with the Khedive’s troops, the other being Captain H.C. Porter. Major Porter en- tered the service in 1894 as a second lieutenant of the 19th Hussars, was promoted captain in 1908, and transferred to the King’s three years later. He was employed with the West. African Frontier Force 1898-1905, and shared in the Borga Expedition, 1898 (medal with clasp); campaign in Northern Nigeria, 1900-01 (mentioned in brevet majority, medal with clasp) ; Kontagora Expedition, 1902 (mentioned in despatches) ; and the Kano-Sokoto Expedition, 1908 (mentioned in despatches, D.S 0., medal with clasp), and he had also a turn in the South African War of 1900.
Bimbashi Wood-Martin, 9th Sadanese, has been granted leave of absence until January 1, 1908.
Bimbashi Jennings-Bramly, Janior Inspector, Mongalla Province, is due back from lesve on December 4.
Bimbashi Greaves, Deputy Assistant Civil Secretary, has received extension of leave until November 28.

Second Lieutenant Viscount Feilding has been placed on duty with the draft being prepared by the home battalions of the Cold- stteam Guards to join the 3rd Battalion, at Cairo. The draft will embark for Alexandria on the last day of the month.

The following officers of the Egyptian Army and Officials of the Sudan Government are due back from leave this month :—Miralei Matthews Bey, Governor, Upper Nile Province, Kaimakam Bey, Assistant Adjutant General, Kaimakam Jackson Bey, Officer Com- manding, 1st Battalion, Kaimakam Garvice Bey, D.8.0., Officer Commanding, Arab Batta- lion, Bimbashi Thompson, Medical Corps, Bimbashi Logan, Deputy Assistant Adjutant General.

The following have returned from leave and resumed duty :—Miralai ‘Turner Bey; Director of Posts and Telegraphs, Kaimakam Leigh Bey, D.S.O, O.C. 4th Battalion, Kaimakam Charlton Bey, Assistant Military Secreaty, Bimbashi, Percival Jun. Insp. Bahr El Ghazal Province, Bimbashi Huntly Walsh, Steamers and Boats Dept., Bimbashi McLeod, 14th Sudanese Bimbashi Lord, Railways Dept., Bimbashi Wise, Oamel Corps, Bimbashi Huskisson, Attached Bahr El Ghazal Disctrict, Bimbashi Hadow, 9th Sudanese, Bimbashi Lamb, Jun. Insp., Sennar Province

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: CRICKRT AT PORT SAID.

On Saturday last the Port Said International Sproting Club played the return cricket match with the Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Co., and were again defeated. A.J. Tweedie and Brooks opened for the P. and O. while the bowling was taken on by De Rougemont and Field. In the second over Tweedie hit De Rougemont clean out of the ground for 6 and in the next over from the same bowler secured 3 foura. With the score at 41 Brooks was run out, through smart fielding by White. Rush and Tweedie were not together long, the latter player being caught at cover from a very loose ball. With Wallis and Rush together a splendid stand was made, both baseman hitting with freedom and treating the bowling with a certain amount of contempt. Rush before he had reached double figures was badly missed by King in the long field. White who replaced Field, had ver hard luck in not securing any wickets. King replaced De Rougemont ater he had had 71 runs knocked off him, and in the new bowler's second over caught and bowled Wallis who had contributed a useful 24 by good cricket, and in the same over of 50 included 6 fours, 4 threes, and 3 twos. The remainder of the batsmen were all dis- missed fofr single figures. Field and De Rouge- mont were the first partners for the club. The latter player unfortunately was run out during the second over. In the next over Field was l.b.w and in the following one White and Rodger were dismissed. With the socre at 9 runs for 4 wickets things were looking any thing but rosey. The next three wickets added 54 and the remainder of the side collapsed. The scoring was as follows:-

div.head: Cario's Threatened Cab Strike.
div.p: Who are the Agitators
Mohamed Bey Wahid, leader of the Eygpt- ian Liberal Party, addresses the following letter to "Al Mokattam":-

"Sir---I have beem informed that the agita- tors and opponents of the Occupation are encourgaing the arbaghis to make a demonstra- tion on November 9, the anniversary of King Edward's birthday. They have also asked Mustapha Pasha Kamel to rouse the lower classes at Alexandria to use unseemly language at the meeting

div.head: Notes from Yemen
div.p: The Mecca Commission
(From Our Own Correspondent) Aden, October 15.

Advice from Yemen state that the Commis- sion from Meccs to the Imam (mentioned in a previous letter), whose departure was postponed last month, has now arrived at Hodside and has proceeded to Sana. The Commission from Mecca consists of four Ulemas and Sheriffs. The Pilgrim Season
The pilgrim season has begun. The steamers "Mozaffar" and "Zobinghla" have passed here from Bombay en-route to Jedda, having on board 592 and 884 pilgrims, respectively

div.head: The Cotton Market
div.p: Messrs Collinge Brothers, report from Liver- pool under date of the 12th inst., that the market has been fairly active then peak and flunctuations in "features" have been frequent

Yesterday showed the erractic nature of the market at present: the very down, then 3 to 4 points were recovered after- wards easing off again but dropping finally at only about 2 points lower on the dow.
The spot demand had been goo thoughout the week
The South still holds on to it cotton and offers are dear,
Crop movement continues very small

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Angjourd hui 2 midi)

Le marché a présenté ce matin le méme aspect déprimié que la semaine passde. était d’aillears & prévoir avec 1a faiblesse du Stook Exchange. L’animation a fait complétement défant et les quelques transactions effectuées ont été limitées a un petit nombre de titres ; de plas, comme tous les jours précédents, elles n’ont eu aucune importance. Quant 4 la ten- danee, elle est indécise, pour ne pas dire plus.

On échangé quelques actions United 4 9/82, quelques Agricole a 8 7/32, Union Fon- cidre & 4 18/16 et Cassa di Sconto a 50. L'U nion Foncidre était l'objet d’ahe demande, ainsi que la Khedivial Mail en hausse de ce chef de 22/3 a 22/61’Ordinary et de 41/8 A 4 1/4 te Privildgiée.
Comme ou be voit par le gain de 2 francs, la Cassa a été également soutenne.

C'est a pea pres tout ce qu'il y a A dire pour la séance de ce matin, les autres valeurs n’ayant pas été abordées, ou n’ayant donné lieu qu’a des offres sans résultats on bien a des transactions insignifiantes.

Les titres les plus éprouvés par le monve- ment baissier sont la National Bank en perte de 1/44 21 5/8, la Béhéra de 38/8 4 23 1/2, les Sucreries de 5 francs 435, les Splendid Hotels de 1/8 4 4 1/4, le Comptoir de 3/32 a 2 25/82 l'ancienne et 2 27/82 la nouvelle, la Building Lands de 8/32 & 1 15/16.

En baisse égal les Joui Eanx du Gaire de 194 & 192, la Banque d’Athénes de 110 a 109, la Delta Land de 11/241 15/82, la fondatear Comptoir de 2 1/16 a 2, le Banco di Roma de 105 @ 104, la Banque Orient de 120 a 119, la Port Said Salt de 18/6 & 18/14.
Lobtigation angienne Crédit Foncier pro gresse de 296 4 297, tandis que la nouvelle rétrograde de 254 & 253.

La Galt and Soda bénéficie «le 3 pence A 18/-, ¥Investment de 1/32 & 7/16, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 3/82 a 4 7/82, la Levant de 1/32 4 17/82, la Levico de 1/32 l'action A 15/32 et 1/4 la fondateor & 3 1/2.

Sar le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de change ment appréciable a signaler, sinon qne plu siears titres ont va transformer leurs prix acheteurs en prix vendeurs; mais ces détails nous entraineraient trop loin.
Il a été vendu aux enchéres publiques 75 Langhis 4 13/64 et 125 4 15/64, ainsi que 350 Actions United a 9/32.

On nous signale une demande assez suivie en terrains de cultare. L'Union Fonciére et plusieurs autres sociétés du méme genre con cluent presque journellement de nouvelles affaires. La Sidi Salem, entre autres, vendrait quotidiennement ou a pen pres des lots A «les prix variant de 65 & 100 livres le feddan. ("est une bonne note a I'actif des soeiétés en question.

Samedi matin,a eu liea l'Assemblée des actionnaires de la (iwezireh Mansions Limited, sous la présidence de M. Preyer, assisté de M. Skynder, administrateur-délé- gué,et de plasiears autres membres du conseil

Le président expose comment le Conseil a été amené A créer 90 parts en participation de 4000 L.B chacune, en vue de se procurer les fonds nécessaires Ala construction de sept im meubles de rapport sur le lot A, sis 4 Guezireh Palace Gardens.
Ces parts, qui jouiront d'un revenu 9 %, sont déja presque toutes souscrites et le solde sera placé avant la fin de l'année
A l'unanimité l'Assemblée approuve le projet du conseil et lui donne pleins pouvoirs d’en assurer l’excécution.
L’Assembiée ratifie, également a |'unanimite, la nomination comme membres du conseil d'administration de MM. Robert Scott, Allet et Morcos bey Fahmy.

Sur la proposition de plusieurs actionnaires, appnyée chaleareusement par Maitre Garbua, des remerciements et des félicitations sont votésau conseilet particulicrement 4 M. Skyn der, administrateur-délégué, pour la facon brillante dont ils ont conduit les affaires de la spcigté, an moment oii la crise finan cidze rendait leur mission particuliérement dif- ficile.
Les potionnaires présents ont po admirer les plans de l'une des constructions, qui va étre incessamment-commencée dans l’un des terrains que posséde Ia Société & Guézireh.
Ces plans, dUs 4 M. Lasciac, architecte de Ia Bogidté, nous ont paru satisfaire & toutes les nécessités du confort moderne, en méme temps qu’aux régles du meilleur got archi tectaral.

div.head: TELEGRAMS.
div.p: HOME RAILWAY CRISIS
CONFERENCE IN MANCHESTER.
A WORKMEN'S BREACH ENDED.
Lonpox, October 19 British railway companies are organising with a view to emergencies. (Reuter)

London, October 20. An important stage of the railway fight was reached yesterday evening. At a conference in Manchester six railway workers Unions, representing 140,000 men, agreed to join the forces and sapport the Amalgamated Society of Railway Servants’ claim for recognition. This decision ends the breach between the Amalga- mated Society of Railway Servants and the Engine Drivers Association (Reuter)

div.head: THE MOROCCAN SITUATION
div.p: HAFID'S FRUITLESS MISSION.
YELLOW BOOK IN PREPARATION
Udspa, October 19. Several tribes demand the aman. (Havas)
Paris, October 20. M. Pichon is preparing a Yellow Book on the events in Morocco ( Havas )
CASABLANCA, October 20. Daring a reconnaissance towards Saddert six French were killed, Captain Ihlar and a horse man, and six wounded (Havas)
Rome, October 20. Mulay Hafid’s envoys have been refused audiences at the Court and Embassies here. (Reuter)
Rome, October 20. The delegates of Mulay Hafid obtained no audiences ; they have left for Amsterdam (Havas)

div.head: THE PEACE CONFERENCE.
div.p: PRESIDENTS CLOSING SPEECH

The Hague, October 19 At the closing of the Peace Conference the President, M. de Nelidof, said that the Inter national Prize Court would be the Conference's monument. He warmly repelled the accusation that nothing had been done for the mainten ance of peace, and sajd that useful foundations had been laid for their successors to build upon. Sir Edward Fry, replying to M. de Neli doff, said he hoped that a system of really international law would form the ground of the Prize Court.
The Chinese delegate intimated that he was unable to sign the Convention in the absence of instructions. ( Reuter)

div.head: EMPEROR JOSEPH’S HEALTH
div.p: CONTINUED IMPROVEMENT
Vienna, October 19. The Emperor passed the best night for a week lust night. His condition is altogether satisfactory. ( Reuter )
Vienna, October 19. The Emperor's health continues to improve ( Havas )
Vienna, October 20. The improved state of the Emperor is main tained. The doctors consider his Majesty con valescent (Havas)

div.head: LORD CROMER AND FREEDOM OF CITY
div.p: LUNCHEON AT MANSION HOUSE

London, October 20. Lord Cromer will be presented with the freedom of the City at the Guildhall on 28th instant. The presentation will be followed by a lunch at the Mansion House. include Sir E. Grey, Mr. Morley, Lord Carzon, Lord Milner and Lord Revelstoke. (Renter)

div.head: ITALY’S LABOUR DIFFICULTIES.
div.p: RAILWAY STRIKE AVERTED.
Rome, October 19.
The State Railways Administration has dis- missed 15 ringleaders and degraded 3,000 others. If the Government will ratify this another general strike is expected as a reta- liation (Reuter)
Turin, October 19.
The Council of the Labour Federation has decided against an eventual strike. (Reuter)
Rome, October 19 The Socialist Managing Committee has passed a resolution against the strike which is likely to be abortive (Reuter)
Rome, October 19 The general strike of railway employés will not take place. (Havas)

div.head: THE PERSIAN SITUATION
div.p: CABINENTS RESIGNATION IMMINENT.
TRHERAN, October 20. Several ministers have been censured by the majority who demand the resignation of the Cabinet. The resignation is imminent.
Order at Kerman has been restored. Serious disorders have again broken out at Shiray. (Reuter)

div.head: LONDON’S MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS.
div.p: 1,200 SOCTALIST CANDIDATES
London, October 19 There are 1,200 socialist candidates for the forthcoming municipal elections, as compared with 722 last year. (Reuter)

div.head: FLOODS IN FRANCE.
div.p: DISASTROUS DAMAGE OF PROPERTY
Paris, October 19. Renewed floods have occurred in the South and in the valleys of the Rhone and Loire. They are most serious and are damaging pro perty disastrously (Reuter)

div.head: HURRICANE IN THE CHANNEL
div.p: FEARFUL SPEED OF WIND
London, October 19 A hurricane is raging in the Channel. The wind is sometimes 60 miles an hour. Vessels are everywhere running for shelter. (Feuter)

div.head: STORAGE OF ELECTRICITY.
div.p: WILL REVOLUTIONISE TRACTION

New York, October 20. Edison has annoonced that he has perfected the electric storage battery whereby it is pos sible to store electricity in bulk without exces. sive weight. He expects that this will revolu tionise the systems of traction and cheapen motors (Reuter)

div.head: CASABLANCA INDEMNITIES.
div.p: NOTE TO THE POWERS
Paris, October 19 France and Spain have remitted identical notes to the Powers proposing the settlement of the Casablanca indemnities by an interna tional commission (Havas)

div.head: OTTOMAN MISSION IN ROME.
div.p: Rome, October 19 The Ottoman Mission viehed bones Peak (Havas)
Rome, October 20. A special mission from the Sultan handed the Hanedani Order to the King on Saturday. A royal banquet was given in honour of the mission to-day. (Reuter)

div.head: STORMS IN ITALY.
div.p: Rome, October 20. A great storm has devastated the vine-yards around Mount Etna Catania is partly flooded. (Reuter)

div.head: ABYSSINIAN MISSION AT ATHENS.
div.p: Artuens, October 19. M. Skonzes entertained the members of the Abyssinian mission at launch, the head of which has been decorated with the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Saviour and the members with other orders. (Reuter)

div.head: PRINCE GEORGE’S MARRIAGE.
div.p: Athens, October 19. The marriage of Prince George with Princess Marie Bonaparte will be solemnised here between the 22nd and 28th November.(Reuter)
Athens, October 19. Prince George's martiage will take place at the end of November. (Havas)

div.head: THE WHEAT DIFFICULTY.
div.p: London, October 19. It is stated that Germany is largely baying wheat in the Eastern Counties which hitherto imported German wheat. (Reuter)

div.head: WIRELESS MESSAGE INTERCEPTED.
div.p: Halifax (Nova Scotia), October 19. The Marconi station at Glace Bay picked up unintendingly a wireless message from Manila announcing the arrival of the “Philadelphia,” a distance of 12,000 miles. (Reuter)

div.head: A TUMULTUOUS SKUPSHTINA.
div.p: Belgrade, October 19. The Skupshtina has opened. The Premier read an Ukase adjourning it till 5th December with a view to the renewal of the negotiations with Austria. An uproar ensued, the Opposi tion shouting him down with cries of “lawless- ness” and “murderers.” (Reuter)
Belgrade, October 19 The Skoupchina has been opened and ad- journed immediately in a tumult. (Havas)

div.head: CHOLERA IN RUSSIA.
div.p: HEAVY MORTALITY
St. Petersburg, October 20. There have been 8299 cases of cholera in Russia from the 16th July to 15th October, 3995 of which proved fatal. (Reuter)

div.head: TOWN ON FIRE.
div.p: Kowno, October 20. The town ot Ponievege is on fire. (Havas)

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN FINANCIAL CRISIS
div.p: We have received a lengthy pamphlet by Mr. C. W. Smith entitled “Options and Futures.” The author of this manitest who claims 45 years experience in the financial and commercial world publishes at the com- mencement of his pamphlet copies of letters addressed by him to H. M. the King and to the chairmen of the leading Joint Stock and Banks and Bankers as well as a circular to all interested Governments in which he strongly denounces international and gambling.

A perusal of his pamphlet leaves a pleasant idea of a man thoroughly earnest in purpose who has devoted all his experience to the propagation of his views on one absorbing study in the hope of benefiting in particular his countrymen and we can readily concede the claims he makes in his preface; “my desire is, as ithas been in the past, to do some good in the world while I have the money, he alth and strength to do it.”

With his views we are toa very great ex- tent in sympathy but we consider that he attributes altogether too great influence on the rise in prices to international combines, ignor- ing the fact that prices must necessarily be effected by the production of gold, the medium of exchange, anad that the investments in stocks and shares cannot be high while raw prodace is also high on account of active trade.

Like most men of strong conviction and single purpose Mr. Smith ignores criticism ; for dialecticians, economists and theorists he hasa fine manly contempt and brushes aside their contentions without troubling himself to examine them. Needless to say, that Mr. Smith is intensely patriotic : to save the in vestments of his countrymen from the unscrn- pulous manipulation of American, English, Jewish or foreign capitalistic gamblers he would extend Leeman’s Financial Bank Act of 186 7 to all private properties but with five year's imprisonment A la Canada’s (Bourse) Criminal Court Act of 1892.
We give in full his remarks on Egypt :—

As all Governments are aware, an Inter- national Judicial Commission has been sitting in Egypt during the past three years to deal with the questions of financial and commer- cial gambling and of reforming the Bourse gambling-laws of that country. This commis sion comprised delegates from the following seventeen countries interested in the economic welfare, and responsible for the maintenance ofthe law order, and good government, of that conntry—viz,—Great Britain, France, Germany, Austria, Hungary, Belgium, Den- mark, Spain, the United States of America, Greece, Italy, the Netherlands, Portugal, Russia, Sweden, Norway, and, of course, Egypt. This commission, twelve months ago, appoint ed a small sub-commission to deal with the matters in question.

The report of that commission has been lately published. In a few words it advises the acceptance, pure and simple, of the Govern- ment's project. This purposes to permit a free action of the outrageous gambling operations (agiotage) which has been in vogne in Egypt for many years in certain agricultural pro- ducts, especially in cotton. In fact, the door would be again opened to the corruption, oppression, and injnstice, which at one time were the only form of rule known in Egypt. And, as Monsieur Vercamer, the eminent Belgian judge and delegate, truly points out in his powerful Mémoire,1 published in June, 1907, on this proposed project, “it is a system of ‘radicalism’ that has no equivalent in any of the European legislations.”

But, before the project, as advised by the sub-commission in their report, becomes the law in Egypt as the basis for future Bourse- gambling, it will be necessary for the Govern- ments of all the other interested nations to give their consent. Under these circumstances let me briefly set forth for their benefit, and especially for that of the British Government, the numerous examples of the rnin caused to Egypt during the past two years only, by Bourse-gambling. not only in stocks and shares, but also in marchés a terme of cotton and of other products.

In 1905, the Egyptian cotton manufactory was ruined. In 1906, the Egyptian Society ot Sugar Refineries was declared bankyupt. In 1906-1907, the Egyptian speculatdrs lost enormous sums of money by gambling opera- tion in “futares” of Egyptian and American Cotton on the Exchanges in Egypt and in Liverpool, England, entailing heavy “liquida: tion” in Egyptian stocks and shares in order to liquidate their losses. Since 1906 there has been a prolonged period of financial depression, caused solely by over-speculation and rank gambling on the Egyptian Bourses, not only in the above commodities, but also in stocks and shares. This culminated in June, 1907. The result is that the values of all classes of Egyptian securities and properties have fallen heavily, even to 60 per cent., thus affecting the values of land and the general welfare of the country, and ending in a financial and commercial crisis. So serions has this crisis been that the Bourses of Cairo and Alexandria had to be temporarily closed for some days, owing to the “Bears” proving victorious. The losses have not only fallen upon Egypt, but also upon London, Paris, Vienna, Manchester, &. All classen of property have (more or less) i the principal banking in- stitutions of Eygpt, while one important bank, with branches in Cairo and in Alexandria, and

* A manifesto on international, financial and commercial Gambing in "Opinions and Futures" (marchés a terme of teh world's greatest perils an imperative demand for inter- national legislation by Charles William Smith (of fourty-five years' experience in the financial and commercial world). Price, post free, eightpence. London P. S. King & Son Orchard House, Westminster, 1907
especially mixed up with Bourse gambling transactions, suspended payment with enorm- ous liabilities; and so on

This, however, is only another example to prove the chaos which must inevitably fall upon a country by permitting international gambling operations in “options and futures.” If the new project becomes law it can only terminate in the ultimate ruin of Egypt, as per ithe final ing-up in my open letter of of June, 1905, to Lord Cromer, published in my last book, which, judging by the weighty words of Lord Cromer himself, as pat forth in lhis various official reports since 1904, he partly lagrees with, especially in connection with the most important question of gambling in cotton, lan article which he forcibly points out “forms the principal basis for the wealth of Egypt.”
Therefore, let the “Bears” of this commodity lonce again obtain the upper hand, as they did in the latter years of the past century, and the fate of Egypt is sealed.

div.head: EGYPTOLOGICAL NOTES.
div.p: THE ALEXANDRIA NECROPOLIS

Before leaving Egypt after his explorations lat Elephantine M. Clermont Ganneau visited Alexandria and went to see the excavations being carried on by Dr. Breccia on behalf of the Alexandria Museum in the necropolis to the east of the city. In one of the sepulchres M. (Ganneau noticed a painted | inseriptien which appeared to have been in Mébrew letters and so suggested that part, if not all, of the tombs were those of Jews or Semites. Later Dr. Breccia forwarded to him a cast of another graven text in which he was able to deci an epitaph of a personage named Akabyah, son lof Elioenai, both characteristic Jewish names and the second similar to a name in the Old Testament meaning “Unto Jehovah I lift up my eyes.”

M. Ganneau says that the style of the alphabet of this inscription recalls most laccurately that of other texts of the Persian period in Egypt in various Aramaic writings, and so it is probably of early Ptolemaic times. This discovery determines [brahimiye, sl three kilometers east of Alexandria, as the site of a Hehrew eemetery before the Christian era.
Statues at Karnak

M. Iegrain reports that the collection of statues and statuettes from the well close to the pylon of the hypostyle hall at Karnak has not yet been completely recovered. Altogether 29 large statues and 720 smaller ones, and stelae, and about 17,000 statuettes have been found. Lately the chief relics brought to the surface have been a kneeling statue of one of the Rameses, an erect one of the son of Sabaco, and fragments of a large statue of Ameno- phis III
Menepthah’s Mummy

Professor Elliot Smith who unrolled and examined the mummy found in the tomb of Teie and pronounced it to be that of a young man has under the instruction of M. Maspero removed the wrappings from the mummy thought to be that of Menepthah and usually supposed to be the Pharaoh who pursued the Israelites to the Red Sea. From the writing on the swathings, and the resemblance of the features to Rameses I] and Seti, the father and grandfather of Menepthah, it is probable that M. Maspero is correct in thinking the body was his. If so, Professor Elliot Smith’s investigation indicates that at his decease the king was “a somewhat corpulent old man with ouly a narrow fringe of white hair and posses- sing but few remaining teeth.” The mommy had been much injured by tomb plunderers and so is not so well preserved as many of the other Egyptian royalties. A full deseription of the research may be found in the “Annales da service des antiquités de l’Egypte” for 1907.
A Pharaoh's Cartouche

At a recent meeting of the. French Academy M. Alfred Merlin, director of antiquities in ‘Tanis, annonnced that during some exca- vations which are being carried on in the Punic cemetery upon the site of ancient Car- thage a tomb had been discovered which con tained an Egyptian vase, being the car- touche of the Pharton Amasis. Other relics having this monarch’s name have been found in countries near to Egypt, previonsly, the reason being probably because be employed mercenaries recruited from countries bordering upon the Mediterranean.
Alexandria's Founder.

To an inhabitant of Alexandria any infor- mation concerning the ancestors of Alexander the Great must be of interest, and therefore we refer to a letter published in the “Athe- naeum” from Mr. W. R. Paton which throws light upon the conqueror’s grandmother.

By a more correct interpretation of a pas sage in a treatise of Plutarch he shows that this lady, whose name was Eurydice, was of Illyrian descent and that her father’s name was Hirrhas. The extract ftom Plutarch is an epigram ot Earydie¢s own composition in which she refers to her sons and’ her knowledge of letters. It is evident that she was a woman of great parts, a worthy mother of Philip and progenitor of the great ALexander
Joseph Offord
